captions.text: My latest novel, Will Destroy the Galaxy for Cash, has been out on audio book for ages yes. But, now the
print and ebook versions are available from all good retailers courtesy of Dark Horse books. All the same
words but now you get to know how all the names are spelled.

Ah, Vikings. Who doesn&#39;t like Vikings? English 
monasteries? Oh right. Anyone who&#39;s ever been

forced to listen to Norwegian black metal? Yes, 
thank you. The point was, in the games industry,

it seems to be only a matter of time before you 
go full Viking. God of War did it, Assassin&#39;s

Creed are doing it, that new Elden Ring thing that 
From Software are doing isn&#39;t strictly full Viking

I know but it&#39;s definitely giving it some funny 
looks. Fair play to Assassin&#39;s Creed, it held out

longer than a lot of series would, I mean, it did 
the fucking American War for Independence before

it did vikings, that&#39;s like forcing yourself to 
eat all the party napkins before you can have

any of the birthday cake, but there&#39;s no putting 
off going full Viking forever. It&#39;s one of the

points on the graph. Ninjas, pirates, vikings. 
And I guess maybe cowboys. Hey! Is that a Ubisoft

drone? Oh shit it&#39;s taking notes! Sorry everyone, 
don&#39;t know how they keep getting in here. If they

announce Assassin&#39;s Creed Deadwood next year I 
guess you can all blame me. Anyway, Vikings and

Norse mythology have always been fairly prevalent 
in the world of video games. Not sure why. Maybe

it&#39;s because it hits all the right notes. It&#39;s 
not just that we get to cleave motherfuckers in

twain for looking at us funny, it&#39;s that we can 
do it with a silly accent and a nice beard.

So everyone piles into the fun bus to enjoy some 
cleaving in twain but Ubisoft, who let&#39;s not

mince words, are all over the fucking place these 
days, stands in front of the fun bus to go &quot;Ooh,

don&#39;t forget, the Vikings were a nuanced people 
who also did a lot of trading and colonising

when they weren&#39;t cleaving stuff in twain, 
historical accuracy, this game was developed

by a multicultural group of extremely large beards 
and all that.&quot; And I can&#39;t help feeling there&#39;s a

bit of wanting to have one&#39;s roast boar and eat 
it going on here, as we and our group of hairy

tattooed raiders run up to an English monastery to 
smash all the windows and set fire to everyone&#39;s

pubes, and then a monk gets caught in the melee 
between me and the poorly equipped Saxon bodyguard

who was just trying to do his job and the game 
goes &quot;Whoops, don&#39;t kill civilians, or you&#39;ll

desynchronize!&quot; The implication being that killing 
innocent monks is in some way out of character for

someone who is, at that precise moment, pillaging 
a monastery. But let&#39;s wind back a little.

The plot of Assassin&#39;s Creed Valhalla concerns 
Eivor, a Norwegian warrior whose parents are

killed by another Norwegian warrior, but who gets 
revenge before the prologue is over, which, much

like most of the beards involved, leaves things at 
a bit of a loose end. For want of something to do,

and in the wake of Norway being peacefully united 
under Harald Fairhair towards the end of the first

millennium and becoming all lame and non-murdery, 
Eivor decides to sail to medieval England to start

a new life. This being probably the only era 
in history where people went to England to make

their lives MORE interesting. Most other times, 
that&#39;s like going to the Arctic circle for the

beaches. But fate has more in store for Eivor, as 
for some reason a couple of weird dogmatic fellas

with hooded robes and a slight finger deficiency 
are hitching a ride. Let the record now show that,

while the Order of Assassins normally reserved 
their trademark hidden blades for the actual

sworn-in devotees to their cause, it seems 
they also occasionally passed them out to

randoms if they seem even vaguely into the whole 
freedom-from-oppression thing. Or if they just

got dragged along to someone&#39;s party and forgot 
to bring a gift. Because I can&#39;t imagine these

assassins not feeling a little awkward after 
the monastery pillaging starts in earnest.

So we have the second Ubisoft sandbox in as many 
weeks to be set in England. I guess we&#39;re making

the most of it before Brexit really kicks in and 
the British government starts selling off national

monuments for bread. But while Assassin&#39;s Creed 
Valhalla seems to be a lot stabler than Watch

Dogs Legion and my PC runs it without me having to 
constantly hold a sick bag in front of the vents,

it&#39;s also a lot less interesting to talk 
about. Without a unique selling point like

NPC recruitment it&#39;s just another Ubisoft Jiminy 
Cockthroat, another to-do list of samey stealth

action missions with crafting and collectibles. 
While riding over the green hills of merrie

England at one point I suddenly realised that I 
could switch to Ghost of Tsushima at this moment

and probably not fucking notice if it weren&#39;t for 
the main character suddenly wearing a much more

interesting hat. There&#39;s still the bird scouting 
and the RPG elements from the last two games,

but it&#39;s a little closer in spirit to the 
Assassin&#39;s Creed 2 era since you&#39;ve got a

home village to pour resources into and a bit more 
of a story focus, but who the fuck cares. It&#39;s

just another point on the line graph. Another 
shake of the bag full of the same shit.

The only thing that really marks it out is that 
instead of the climbing all over elaborately

realised cathedrals and palaces we got in previous 
games you&#39;re leaping across mud huts and wattling

and fifteen copy pasted examples of the same 
Viking longhouse. Because it&#39;s the fucking dark

ages. And they missed a trick by still having us 
jump into piles of straw and leaves when it would

have been much more authentic to replace them with 
gigantic piles of shit. I guess Ubisoft thought

that might have been a little uncomfortably 
representative of the company&#39;s trajectory over

the years. The initial spark of getting to play 
a burly Viking can&#39;t be sustained through the

subsequent forty hours of trudging through mud and 
dealing with political squabbles between people

dressed in earthtones in the name of Assassin&#39;s 
Creed&#39;s trademark historical accuracy. I was

getting sniffy about the ethical ramifications of 
monastery pillaging earlier but if anything the

game should&#39;ve leaned more into that. Let us tear 
shit up swinging a giant fucketh-off hammer as

our muscles bulge like mating walruses and seduce 
all the hot monk chicks away from their inadequate

monk boyfriends. It&#39;s this trying to hit all the 
points at once thing that muddles the tone.

Trying to make out like we&#39;re some kind of freedom 
fighter while we laughingly set all the pigsties

ablaze and hunt down the usual laundry list of 
Templars that we are assured are evil but who seem

to be mostly minding their own fucking business. 
There&#39;s an RPG skill tree split between melee,

ranged or stealth focussed builds, but you have 
to do all three at various times so there&#39;s not

much point in specializing. There isn&#39;t really a 
stealthy way to raid a monastery. I try floating

the idea to my raiding party while we&#39;re 
all sprinting up to the gate waving axes

but turns out it&#39;s hard to talk with your 
shield between your teeth. And there&#39;s the

longboat because having your own ship has 
ticked enough boxes in previous Assassin&#39;s

Creed games to keep bringing back, but lacking a 
need for ocean travel it&#39;s just there for moving

quickly along rivers and there&#39;s no boat 
combat, unless you notice a particularly

antisocial-looking frog. So that&#39;s Assassin&#39;s 
Creed Valhalla. Noteworthy only for its extreme

unnoteworthiness. What a dull way to end the 
video. Here&#39;s a picture of a leopard in a scarf.
